Award.AwardTitle: System of Systems Approach and Uncertainty Mitigation/Exploitation for Wind Farm Design

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this research is to make it possible to design wind farms with significantly higher power generation capacity (a 25 to 30 percent increase from existing designs). A comprehensive system of systems approach to wind farm design will be developed which addresses the concomitant pervasive uncertainty through, both mitigation and exploitation. We will build on existing work in the supporting technological areas of wake modeling, wind farm power generation modeling, economics modeling, and optimal design for computationally prohibitive multidisciplinary systems. The major research activities include: (i) optimization, design, and uncertainty propagation; (ii) economic modeling; (iii) development of product family approaches; (iv) developing and parameterizing power output model of wind turbine arrays; and (v) validation of models. Guidelines will be developed that will directly assist engineers, researchers, and investors in their pertinent decision-making.

If successful, the unique approach to dealing with the uncertainty-ridden system and the system of system approach being developed here, can enable the scientific community to achieve a new level in addressing our current and future energy requirements. A unique interdisciplinary environment will be provided to students who are motivated by the grand challenge of achieving 20% electric power using wind by 2030, and by the desire to be prepared for green jobs in the context of a rapidly changing economic landscape. Periodic exchange visits by faculty members, graduate and undergraduate students between the two institutions (RPI and SU) will provide the students with unique preparations. A key anticipated benefit of the proposed research is the increased likelihood of reaching our critical goal of having 20% of our electricity come from wind energy by 2030, which is a high national priority.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The scholarly outcomes of this project range from fundamental contributions to the theory of complex system optimization and atmospheric boundary layer interactions within wind farms, to the generation of new knowledge regarding designing high-performance uncertainty-aware wind farms. On the educational front, the outcomes primarily include training of an exceptional number of next generation scholars. These outcomes are described below:

Intellectual Merit: The research objectives of this project were two-fold: 1) generating a deeper understanding and quantification of the nonlinear interactions between the atmospheric boundary layer (ABL) and wind turbines and associated impact of wind resource uncertainties; and 2) advancing the theory of complex system optimization to address these nonlinearities in designing the layout of utility-scale wind farms. Towards the first objective, wake measurements of field-installed/scaled-model wind turbines were performed for various ABL conditions. It was demonstrated that the buoyancy jumps at the wake-freestream interface have an adverse effect on the momentum transport when the ABL is stably-stratified, leading to greater persistence of wake velocity deficit compared to the neutral boundary layer case. These findings imply significantly smaller (than previously understood) amount of energy is available to be extracted from the wind downstream from the first few rows of turbines, thereby seriously undermining the traditional approach (and current industrial practice) of arranging turbines in an array-like row/column layout. In addition to resolving the spatial and short-term transient scales of the ABL, our investigations of the wind resource uncertainties showed that the distribution of wind speed and direction over months/years did not necessarily follow parametric probability distributions typically used in wind resource assessment. Non-parametric distribution models (based on kernel density estimation) were developed to accurately capture wind resource variations over longer time scales.

Another key outcome of this project was the development and testing of a robust Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) algorithm to solve mixed-integer non-linear programming (MINLP) problems. The findings from the ABL investigations indicated that very different wind conditions are experienced by wind turbines located on the upstream edge, downstream edge, and inside the wind farm. This supported our hypothesis that, contrary to the current practice, different types of turbines must be installed at these different locations to take advantage of their suitability to different wind conditions. This demanded coherent optimal decisions regarding the type and location of wind turbines. Together with the nonlinearities of the wind flow dynamics and resource variations, this led to a complex MINLP problem, the solution of which was difficult with existing MINLP solvers – thus motivating our MINLP version of the PSO algorithm. In a comprehensive benchmark testing effort, our PSO algorithm compared favorably with other powerful heuristic MINLP solvers. This algorithm has been used to not only successfully design layouts of simulated utility-scale wind farms ranging in size from 25 turbines to 500 turbines, but also solve problems with similar mathematical characteristics in the domains of energy-efficient building operation and unmanned aerial systems design.

 

Broader Impact: By obviating limiting assumptions (of the existing state of the art) such as an array layout and fixed/uniform type of turbines, the wind farm layout optimization methods developed in this project demonstrated potential increase in energy production capacity of 5-15%, thus laying the foundation of a new (exciting) paradigm in wind energy economics. On the front of educating and training research scholars, this project far exceeded its initial objectives. This project trained a total of four PhD students (all graduated) – two of them now hold tenure-track faculty positions in Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering (at U Buffalo and UT Dallas); another is pursuing a Post-Doctoral fellowship in the area of data science and energy efficiency (at Columbia U), and the fourth is pursuing a career in the optimization software industry (at Siemens). Outcomes of this project has led to the augmentation of existing and the development of new graduate level courses, such as the Heuristic (nature-inspired) optimization course current taught by PI Chowdhury at U Buffalo. During 2013 and 2014, TTU established a summer research institute for minority students (a total of ~27 + 42 students participated), leveraging internal funds and this NSF sponsorship. Focus topics included Renewable Energy and Medicine. Participating Undergraduate and K-12 students were exposed to world-renowned scholars by means of collaborative projects, seminars and workshops, motivating them towards higher education in STEM areas and improving their communication skills.

Products: Major products resulting from this project include: ~16 peer-reviewed journal articles, more than 25 ASME/AIAA full-length conference articles, optimization and modeling software artifacts (critical codes are available publicly in MATLAB file-exchange), graduate level course content, and K-12 workshop material. The large number of technical publications resulting from the project, which include top cited articles in the area of wind farm design (e.g., Renewable Energy Journal Top Paper award winner), further corroborates the continuing impact of this project.
